chapter.title: Received Standby LC
chapter.para: The features gathered under the term of Trade Middle-Office are related to the actions taken by a bank playing an active role in a Trade Finance transaction existing in as a product record.

All the products (Import and Export Letters of Credit, Shipping Guarantees, Financing Requests, Export and Import Documentary Collections, Banker's Guarantees, Issued and Received Standby LCs, Fund Transfers and Inward Remittances) available in the system can be manipulated using the Trade Middle-Office module, using the functions on the menu that you access by clicking Middle-Office on the main menu on your home page.

section.title: Categories of Action
section.para: In this module you can do the following:

varlistentry.term: Reply to an initiation submitted to the bank by one of its clients

listitem.para: By "initiation", we mean any message sent by the client to the bank. For example, a request for issuance of a new Letter of Credit, an amendment of its terms, the creation of a new Guarantee, a new Financing Request, the delivery of new collection instructions by a drawer to the Remitting Bank, or any update sent using a free format message.

varlistentry.term: Create a new Reporting message on an existing transaction record

listitem.para: This communication is initiated by the bank handling a transaction and is used to notify the customer of a new event that has occurred on the transaction. For example, the Issuing Bank of a Letter of Credit could send an advice of discrepancies to the importer when the documents have been received from the negotiating bank, or alternatively trace its customer for the payment of a sight bill under an LC.

varlistentry.term: Create a completely new transaction record

listitem.para: This is used to notify the export customer of a new Export Letter of Credit (Commercial or Standby) issued in his favour, or to notify a client of a new Import Documentary Collection for which that client is the designated drawee.

varlistentry.term: Initiate a Letter of Credit request on behalf of a client

listitem.para: This module also contains some special functions whereby you can create a Letter of Credit request, on behalf of a client.

section.para: Each of these categories represents an option appearing as a menu item of the Middle Office screen, which you reach from your home page.

In all cases, you can have several users validate the message before it is sent to the customer. To do this, the bank to sets up an authorisation matrix for its users to implement a four-eyes principle or a jurisdiction based on the amounts reported. This mechanism is the same as the one available on the customer side to provide several levels of control on the submission of transactions.

section.title: Pending Records

note.para: Three of the functions in the Pending Records part of the menu do not relate to pending records, but are used to create a new Letter of Credit on behalf of a client. These are described in the section Pending Records (LC). The functions that do relate to pending records are described here in this section.

section.para: The pending records that you see are the transaction events that have been submitted to your bank by its clients. They are now waiting for an acknowledgement by the bank's Trade Services, which has to decide if the related requests can be approved and hence processed in the back-office operations of the bank.

Until a pending record has been approved by the bank through this option, the record is not seen by the client as Existing (if it is a creation of a transaction), Amended or Updated. In other words, its new or updated details have not been committed to the master of this transaction record as long as the acknowledgement has not been applied.
The mechanism of generation of the reply and the associated workflow for the bank user is the following:

listitem.para: You review the list of pending records, either from your home page or from the consolidated list.
You select a record by clicking on its assigned reference number to see more details than the summary appearing in the list.
An input form is displayed with the following capabilities:

You can review the details of the event as well as the full details of the transaction itself. You can print or export these details as a PDF format. You can leave the form for now and return to it later, if some processing / validation is required in the back-office before you can create the acknowledgement message.

After reviewing the details, and after the back-office has processed the request, you can use the first part of the reporting form to enter the text details of the message that will be sent as an acknowledgement to the customer together with any attachments.

note.para: If you need to alter the details of the transaction record as a consequence of the processing by the back-office (for instance if some modifications have been provided by the user by phone), it is advisable to convey these changes in a subsequent reporting message (sent from the Existing Records menu item). This will keep the consistency between the data of the back-office and the file that will be displayed to the customer as part of his reporting. And since it is an additional reporting message, the customer still has access, via the transaction history, to the original details as well as the updated details.

section.title: Pending Records Options
section.para: This action has several sub-menu items, providing different ways to access a pending record.

section.title: List of Records
section.para: Display a list of pending records.

listitem.para: Since these transactional messages are among the most urgent things for a bank user to consider in order to provide the customer with a fast response to business requests, your home page shows a list of the most recently received transactions, under the heading Recent Applications. To avoid a too long a display, the list is limited by default to 10 items. This number can be changed via a properties file. Click an entry in the list to rapidly open the reporting form and show its full details.

section.para: When you select this option, you are presented with a list of requests from clients that have not yet been addressed. Once any user at your bank has started to work on a pending record and has either saved it or tried a submission, that record will not appear in this list but instead in the list displayed by the Retrieve Draft or Retrieve Unsigned sub-menu item.

You can search the list by entering search criteria in the System Id, Company (that sent the request), and/or Product field. (The product can be any of those that enable a client to send a request to the bank.)
There is also a field where you can select an Output Format for the results:

listitem.para: Screen (default) returns the list of matching records on the same page with the usual sorting features.
CSV downloads the list to your machine as Comma-Separated Values file.

section.para: You would typically use the CSV or SpreadSheet option if you want to export the list as a report to use it or customize it further in your office productivity tools). When the browser displays the File Download prompt, you can choose to save the file (whose default name is pendingEL.xxx) or directly open it which will launch Excel if it is available on your workstation.

When you select this option, you are presented with a list of Reporting Messages that have been prepared and saved by users in your bank, but have not been successfully submitted to the clients because the user had insufficient privileges. Records that were simply saved with no attempt to submit them are not included.
Click in the System Id column to open the message in a non-editable mode, so you can review the data and perform the submission.

If you have sufficient authorisation in your profile, you can submit multiple records in a single operation directly from the list. Each record in the list has a check box which you tick to select it. A button at the end of the page submits all the selected records.

The result of the action is then returned, with a list of records that have now been successfully sent to the clients, together with a list of records that have again failed validation. The updated list of unsigned records is then also displayed.

section.title: Existing Records
section.para: For various reasons throughout the life of an International Trade transaction, the bank handling the transaction (as the Issuing Bank of an LC, SI, SG, TF or FT transaction, the Recipient or Issuing Bank for a BG, the Advising Bank for an EL, SR, the Remitting Bank for an EC or IR or the Presenting Bank for an IC) may need to send various transactional messages to its customers.

A typical use of this feature is for the bank to notify an exporter about an amendment to a Export Letter of Credit notified previously in his favour, or for example to forward an advice of discrepancies to the applicant of an Import Letter of Credit.

More generally, the bank can use the generation of reporting from an existing record each time it needs to send a message to the customer and when this event is not a reply to something initiated by the client (in which case it would be accessed through the Pending Records module).
The flow to create these events is similar to the one described for the previous module.

section.title: Issued Standby Letter of Credit Form
Introduction
section.para: Even though it is based on a flow of documents related to a business transaction between a buyer and seller, the Standby Letter of Credit is not directly related to the movement of goods.

It acts more like a guarantee. It means the beneficiary will receive a payment from the Issuing Bank in the event of default on a contract, provided that the complying documents (usually a sight draft) are presented.
A Standby Letter of Credit can be governed by either the UCP 500 rules or the more specific ISP 98 practices.

For business transactions that require regular exchanges between a buyer and a seller, a Standby Letter of Credit can include an Evergreen clause. This means the guarantee is automatically regularly renewed and so does not have an expiry date.

The Issued Standby LC focuses on the applicant side and is therefore very similar to the Import Letter of Credit seen previously. The key difference is that it can also be issued through a fairly unstructured form providing a large text area for the client to enter the details of the requested Standby LC.

When the bank edits a reporting message on this product, the form automatically inherits from the one used for its original issuance: if the Standby LC was initiated through a standard form, the same form as for an Import LC is displayed; if it was issued as a set of free format terms, the related form is loaded.

section.para: A Shipping Guarantee (SG) is an undertaking by a bank to the shipping owner or agent of a vessel, to release goods to the importer pending receipt of the original Bill of Lading. This helps the importer to clear the purchased goods under a Letter of Credit or a simple documentary collection while waiting for shipping documents to be presented. section.title: Introduction
section.para: Documentary Collection is a method of payment used in international trade, whereby the exporter entrusts the handling of trade documents to banks and gives the banks instructions concerning the release of these documents to the importer.

Export Documentary Collection (often abbreviarted to Export Collection) refers to the export side of such transactions where the bank plays the role of the Remitting Bank and where the client is the drawer of the collection.
Two types of Export Collections are handled:

listitem.para: Regular Collections where the remitting bank will be responsible for the sending of the documents to the presenting bank on the import side,
Direct Collections where the drawer himself ships the documents to the presenting bank and only instruct his bank to handle the remaining of the transaction.

section.title: Generating the Cover Letter
section.para: During the initial receipt of the Direct Collection instructions by the Remitting Bank, you can optionally use to generate and submit to your customer the actual cover letter that the customer will use to send directly the documents to the Presenting Bank. This method circumvents a classical flaw of direct collections whereby the Remitting Bank is reluctant to provide its customer with blank forms bearing its letterhead without any control on them.
The built-in flow for the generation and attachment of the cover letter is the following:

listitem.para: The bank receives the request through the middle-office screen and prepares the reporting bearing its approval of the collection instructions.

While performing this task on a direct collection record, you can decide to automatically generate and attach the related cover letter. This is done in Input mode by checking a dedicated check box in the Reporting Message Details section of the screen. At any time, with the icon
, you can call a preview of the letter available as an Acrobat PDF file.

When you click Save / Submit, the server-side logic generates a new attachment and adds it to the list of files attached to the reporting message. This PDF file becomes the original copy that the customer will receive, and subsequently print and attach to the documents sent to the import side.

section.title: Fund Transfer Product
section.para: In an international trade transaction, a client can use this (FT) module to request a fund transfer, for which the bank (called the Ordering Bank) can subsequently send an acknowledgement upon successful completion.

The module is a simple Cash Management feature. It enables an applicant company to do two types of transfer: Internal, which the client uses to transfer funds between two accounts both belonging to the client, and Outgoing, which the client uses when an external beneficiary is the recipient of the transfer, possibly with another banking institution acting as an intermediary. An outgoing transfer is also called a third-party transfer.

Unlike the other products in , the module is associated with a single event (the submission of the transfer request and the bank's reply), and therefore has no free format message feature for further interaction between client and bank.

Therefore the bank side of the Fund Transfer product is limited to a review of the instructions sent by the client and the interaction is limited to the common input fields available for every reporting message generated by the bank from a pending customer request. See the chapter detailing this common function for further details.
